title: Tech - South China Morning Post
description: The latest technology news, reviews, gadgets, launches and products.

items.title: OpenAI CEO declares ‘code red’ to improve ChatGPT as rivals move in
items.creator: Bloomberg
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: OpenAI CEO declares ‘code red’ to improve ChatGPT as rivals move in
items.content:
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is redirecting internal resources to speed up improvements to ChatGPT, declaring a “code red” situation that will delay work on other initiatives, according to people familiar with the matter.
Altman on Monday sent an internal memo calling for a “surge” to improve ChatGPT, said one of the people, who asked not to be identified discussing nonpublic information. Altman also called for staff to delay progress on other efforts such as autonomous AI agents and advertising, the...

items.title: Tsinghua University sets up research institute in push for robotics talent
items.creator: Ann Cao
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Tsinghua University sets up research institute in push for robotics talent
items.content:
China’s Tsinghua University has set up a new cross-disciplinary institute to undertake robotics research, the latest sign of increased academic support from its top universities as the country doubles down on the embodied intelligence competition with the US.
The Institute for Embodied Intelligence and Robotics will integrate resources from Tsinghua’s different schools, including automation, mechanical engineering, electronic engineering and computer science. Embodied intelligence is a field of...

items.title: Ant Group’s LingGuang a hit as users create millions of flash apps with AI tool
items.creator: Iris Deng
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Ant Group’s LingGuang a hit as users create millions of flash apps with AI tool

images.alt: LingGuang is a multimodal AI assistant from Ant Group. Photo: Handout
images.title: LingGuang is a multimodal AI assistant from Ant Group. Photo: Handout

items.content:
LingGuang, an artificial intelligence vibe coding tool by Ant Group, has become a mini-app factory, helping users create 3.3 million flash apps in the two weeks since its launch, according to the Chinese fintech giant.
Launched on November 18, LingGuang is a multimodal AI assistant that can generate simple apps in as little as 30 seconds in response to the users’ natural language prompts.
Ant is an affiliate of Alibaba Group Holding, which owns the South China Morning Post.
In the past two...

items.title: Why the real AI race is within China and not across the Pacific
items.creator: Jeffrey Wu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Why the real AI race is within China and not across the Pacific
items.content:
For much of the global debate, the race for artificial intelligence (AI) supremacy has been framed as a binary contest between the United States and China. As Washington envisions it, victory hinges on frontier models and compute scale, a battle dominated by a handful of American labs. China is cast as the challenger, constrained by export controls and dependent on catching up.
That narrative is increasingly outdated. China is not pursuing a single AI strategy. It is running three large-scale...

items.title: Huawei-style ‘chip stacking’ seen as a path for China to rival Nvidia’s  GPUs
items.creator: Ann Cao
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Huawei-style ‘chip stacking’ seen as a path for China to rival Nvidia’s  GPUs
items.content:
China is stepping up its chip self-sufficiency push by combining relatively mature chips with new computing architectures in an effort to approach Nvidia’s performance levels, according to a top industry expert.
Logic chips made with a 14-nanometre process, which are generally seen as trailing cutting-edge AI processors, could reach a performance comparable with Nvidia’s 4nm products if they were integrated with high-performance memory and an innovative computing architecture, said Wei Shaojun,...

items.translated_title: ByteDance-powered AI phone snapped up by consumers keen to try agentic assistant

images.alt: Screenshot of the online order page for the ByteDance-powered ZTE Nubia M153. Photo: Handout
images.title: Screenshot of the online order page for the ByteDance-powered ZTE Nubia M153. Photo: Handout

items.content:
The first smartphone running on ByteDance’s artificial intelligence agentic phone assistant sold out on the first day, as consumers jumped at the chance to try the AI-powered gadget that could change the way people use mobile phones.
The ZTE Nubia M153, an “engineering prototype” only available for order online, was keenly sought after thanks to ByteDance’s embedded operating-system-level Doubao Mobile Assistant, which is able to carry out tasks such as booking restaurants or editing photos via...

items.title: Kuaishou debuts multimodal AI video model with ‘Nano Banana’ editing capability

items.translated_title: Kuaishou debuts multimodal AI video model with ‘Nano Banana’ editing capability

images.alt: A screenshot showing the video editing capabilities of Kuaishou’s new model. Photo: Handout
images.title: A screenshot showing the video editing capabilities of Kuaishou’s new model. Photo: Handout

items.content:
Chinese short video platform Kuaishou on Monday launched a new artificial intelligence video generation model to challenge OpenAI’s Sora and start-up Runway in the global market for AI content creation.
Kuaishou, which competes with TikTok’s Chinese sibling Douyin in China, said Kling O1 was the first unified multimodal video model in the industry, based on an architecture that integrated diverse video creation tasks – generation, precise and controllable editing and understanding – into a...

items.translated_title: China’s DeepSeek challenges Google DeepMind with new AI model

images.alt: DeepSeek-V3.2-Speciale is the start-up’s most powerful AI model variant to date. Photo: Handout
images.title: DeepSeek-V3.2-Speciale is the start-up’s most powerful AI model variant to date. Photo: Handout

items.content:
Artificial intelligence start-up DeepSeek has unveiled its most powerful model variant, DeepSeek-V3.2-Speciale, which is said to match Google DeepMind’s new Gemini 3 Pro model in certain tasks, despite the Chinese firm having limited access to advanced semiconductor chips.
The achievement by the open-source lab has sparked extensive discussion within the AI research community as it coincides with the prestigious annual Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems, or NeurIPS.
In its...

items.translated_title: Samsung unveils its first multi-folding phone as competition set to heat up

images.alt: A visitor holds a Samsung Galaxy Z TriFold smartphone during a launch event at a Samsung store in Seoul on Tuesday. Photo: AFP
images.title: A visitor holds a Samsung Galaxy Z TriFold smartphone during a launch event at a Samsung store in Seoul on Tuesday. Photo: AFP

items.content:
Samsung Electronics unveiled on Tuesday its first multi-folding smartphone in a bid to strengthen its position in a sector of the handset market where competition is expected to intensify.
The launch of the Galaxy Z TriFold marks Samsung’s bid to reinforce its footing in a segment where Chinese rivals have been gaining ground, even as analysts said the high price and production challenges meant foldable devices were likely to remain a niche category for now.
The model, priced at about 3.59...

items.title: Nvidia takes US$2 billion stake in Synopsys as AI deal spree accelerates
items.creator: Reuters
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Nvidia takes US$2 billion stake in Synopsys as AI deal spree accelerates

images.alt: The headquarters of Synopsys in Sunnyvale, California, October 23, 2024. Photo: Reuters
images.title: The headquarters of Synopsys in Sunnyvale, California, October 23, 2024. Photo: Reuters

items.content:
Nvidia has invested US$2 billion in chip design software maker Synopsys as part of an expanded multi-year tie-up to jointly develop new tools for designing products across industries using its AI technology.
The deal, unveiled by the companies on Monday, comes as Nvidia has carried out a range of investments, such as those in OpenAI and Anthropic, to try to cement its dominance in the artificial intelligence market.
The Synopsys deal is about shifting the work of several hi-tech industries that...

items.translated_title: Chinese schools offer ‘embodied intelligence’ courses to aid robotics industry

images.alt: A robot of Unitree Robotics gives a combat performance at the World Robot Conference in Beijing on August 8, 2025. Photo: Xinhua
images.title: A robot of Unitree Robotics gives a combat performance at the World Robot Conference in Beijing on August 8, 2025. Photo: Xinhua

items.content:
China is building a talent pipeline for the booming robotics industry, with the country’s top universities launching undergraduate courses in embodied intelligence to support Beijing’s ambitions to overtake the US.
Shanghai Jiao Tong University and Zhejiang University were among a batch of seven prestigious universities that had recently applied to add “embodied intelligence” as a new course, China’s education ministry said in November.
The new programme was driven by the demands of a national...

items.title: Changan Auto becomes latest Chinese carmaker to join humanoid robot bandwagon
items.creator: Ann Cao
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Changan Auto becomes latest Chinese carmaker to join humanoid robot bandwagon
items.content:
Chinese carmakers, which are increasingly deploying robots in factories, are now moving into humanoid robotics following US rival Tesla despite a warning from Beijing about a potential investment bubble.
State-owned Changan Automobile has become the latest entrant into the sector. The Shenzhen-listed company planned to invest 225 million yuan (US$31.8 million) for a 50 per cent stake in Changan Tianshu Intelligent Robotics Technology, according to an exchange filing on Friday.
The company...

items.translated_title: China’s CSSC unveils plans for cruise, deep-sea and nuclear-powered vessels

images.alt: The Adora Magic City required 20 times more worker hours to build than a Capesize bulk carrier, according to CSSC. Photo: Getty
images.title: The Adora Magic City required 20 times more worker hours to build than a Capesize bulk carrier, according to CSSC. Photo: Getty

items.content:
China State Ship­building Corp (CSSC), the world’s largest shipbuilding conglomerate controlling one-third of the global market, has pledged to build more cruise ships, deep-ocean drilling ships and nuclear-powered vessels as part of efforts to diversify its portfolio, according to a senior executive.
Assistant president Ma Yunxiang said on Monday the company’s growing strength in building advanced vessels was reflected in the construction of Adora Flora City, mainland China’s second self-built...

items.translated_title: Beijing’s crypto warning casts shadow over Hong Kong’s stablecoin ambitions
items.content:
Beijing’s explicit denunciation of stablecoins as a financial risk has cast fresh doubt on Hong Kong’s ambitions to become a regulated hub for the asset class, according to legal experts and analysts.
The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) – together with the public security ministry, the cyberspace administration, the top court and other key financial regulators – said in a statement on Saturday that stablecoins did not meet the mainland’s requirements on customer identification and...

items.translated_title: ByteDance teams up with ZTE as China races to take on Apple in agentic AI phones
items.content:
TikTok owner ByteDance has entered the race against Apple to define the future of smartphones by putting its artificial intelligence agent Doubao into a ZTE-made handset.
The Beijing-based company on Monday launched the Doubao Mobile Assistant in a technical preview, describing it as “an operating-system-level collaboration between ByteDance’s Doubao [AI model] and mobile phone manufacturers” that “brings more convenient interaction and richer capabilities”, according to a post on Monday on its...

items.translated_title: Hong Kong crypto exchange HashKey wins listing nod in test of investor appetite

images.alt: The digital asset trading market remains heavily reliant on concentrated tokens, particularly bitcoin and ether. Photo: Shutterstock
images.title: The digital asset trading market remains heavily reliant on concentrated tokens, particularly bitcoin and ether. Photo: Shutterstock

items.content:
Crypto exchange operator HashKey Holdings has cleared its Hong Kong listing hearing after an earlier confidential filing, paving the way for a deal that will test investor confidence in the digital asset sector amid evolving regulation.
The operator of Hong Kong’s biggest licensed crypto exchange could raise up to US$300 million, a reduction from a previous target of around US$500 million, in a listing this month, according to a source familiar with the matter. HashKey did not disclose the size...

items.title: Does tokenisation in China risk a repeat of the P2P lending crisis?
items.creator: Aileen Chuang
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Does tokenisation in China risk a repeat of the P2P lending crisis?
items.content:
The rapid rise of tokenisation risks repeating China’s earlier boom-and-bust cycle in peer-to-peer lending unless clear industry standards are established to ensure discipline and innovation, according to a senior Chinese asset manager.
Some multilevel marketing companies in mainland China have already started holding meetings discussing real-world asset (RWA) tokenisation projects over the past year, raising “genuine concerns” that the nascent industry might be heading towards a...

items.translated_title: Uptick in China’s bitcoin mining prompts debate on tapping energy surplus

images.alt: A representation of bitcoin cryptocurrency is shown in this illustration taken September 10, 2025. Photo: Reuters
images.title: A representation of bitcoin cryptocurrency is shown in this illustration taken September 10, 2025. Photo: Reuters

items.content:
A mild uptick in bitcoin mining in China has prompted calls for Beijing to loosen its restrictions and let the power-hungry industry tap into the country’s oversupply of energy, but experts said the likelihood of China ending its mining ban was low.
China’s bitcoin mining market share by hash rate rose from 13.75 per cent in the first quarter of 2025 to 14.06 per cent in the current quarter, making it the third largest bitcoin mining country behind the US and Russia, according to Hashrate Index,...

items.title: Beyond DeepSeek: Moonshot and MiniMax step up as China’s new frontier AI labs
items.creator: Ben Jiang
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Beyond DeepSeek: Moonshot and MiniMax step up as China’s new frontier AI labs
items.content:
Chinese artificial intelligence start-ups Moonshot AI and MiniMax have emerged as China’s strongest contenders to rival US frontier labs in 2025 – even as DeepSeek has stolen the spotlight as the poster child for the country’s AI ambitions.
Moonshot AI, founded by 33-year-old Yang Zhilin, has sharply raised its profile in China’s AI ecosystem with the launch earlier this month of Kimi K2 Thinking, an upgraded reasoning model.
The system outperformed OpenAI’s GPT-5 and Anthropic’s Claude Sonnet...

items.title: Hong Kong reaps the fruits of fintech seeds sown nearly 10 years ago
items.creator: Enoch Yiu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Hong Kong reaps the fruits of fintech seeds sown nearly 10 years ago

images.alt: HSBC CEO Georges Elhedery (left) takes part in a discussion with Financial Secretary Paul Chan Mo-po (centre) and Standard Chartered CEO at the Hong Kong FinTech Week on November 3. Photo: Jonathan Wong
images.title: HSBC CEO Georges Elhedery (left) takes part in a discussion with Financial Secretary Paul Chan Mo-po (centre) and Standard Chartered CEO at the Hong Kong FinTech Week on November 3. Photo: Jonathan Wong

items.content:
When Alvin Kwock, co-founder of digital insurer OneDegree, took part in the inaugural Hong Kong FinTech Week in November 2016, it was held at a venue suitable for only a few hundred people.
“As it was the first ever fintech event in Hong Kong, only fintech start-ups were interested, no big financial institutions paid attention,” Kwock said. “People did not have a clear idea of fintech as it was still in an exploratory stage.”
In the years since, fintech in Hong Kong has gone through a sea...
